plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the absorption and translocation of trifloxysulfuron in tobacco plants. The results showed that approximately 20% of applied trifloxysulfuron was absorbed within 4 hours of application, reaching a total absorption of 43% after 72 hours. The translocation of trifloxysulfuron within the tobacco plants was limited, with not more than 4% of the herbicide moving out of the treated leaves. The partitioning of radioactivity showed that less than 1.9% of the absorbed trifloxysulfuron accumulated in any specific plant part. The low translocation rates observed in tobacco were consistent with other studies on trifloxysulfuron, where the majority of the herbicide remained in the treated leaves
plant_translocations.reference: Troxler, S. C., Fisher, L. R., Smith, W. D., & Wilcut, J. W. (2007). Absorption, translocation, and metabolism of foliar-applied trifloxysulfuron in tobacco. Weed Technology, 21(2), 421-425.

method.Apply Location: Foliar (application to the adaxial surface of the third leaf)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Greenhouse conditions at approximately 24 ± 2°C, with daily watering, weekly fertilization, and a 16-h photoperiod of natural and supplemental metal halide lighting
method.Chemical Preparation: Technical grade [pyridinyl-2-14C]-trifloxysulfuron with 450.6 kBq/mmol specific activity and 97.8% radiochemical purity; 14C-trifloxysulfuron spot solution prepared in high-performance liquid chromatography-grade water and methanol (1:1 v/v) plus 0.25% v/v nonionic surfactant
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Five 1-ml droplets of 14C-trifloxysulfuron containing 4.3 kBq were manually applied with a microsyringe to the adaxial surface of the previously covered third leaf of each tobacco plant

plant_translocations.content: The research aimed to assess the effects of malathion on the absorption and translocation of foliar-applied 14C-trifloxysulfuron in cotton. Laboratory studies showed that greater absorption of radiolabeled trifloxysulfuron occurred in leaves 4 hours after treatment (HAT) when trifloxysulfuron was tank-mixed with malathion compared to trifloxysulfuron applied alone at the 3-to 4-leaf stage. Translocation of trifloxysulfuron to plant tissue above and below the treated leaf was also greater with the tank-mixture. However, increased foliar phytotoxicity (leaf burning) was observed 24 and 96 HAT with trifloxysulfuron tank-mixed with malathion compared to trifloxysulfuron applied alone. These findings suggest that malathion could potentially reduce the rate of trifloxysulfuron metabolism in cotton.
plant_translocations.reference: Minton, B., Matocha, M., & Senseman, S. (2008). The influence of malathion on trifloxysulfuron absorption and translocation in cotton. Cotton Sci, 12, 48-52.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown from seed in 950 mL plastic cups with potting soil. Thinned to 1 plant/cup at 14 days after planting (DAP) .Grown in lab under supplemental light (650 μmol/m2/s) for 28 d, then growth chamber at 27°C, 12 h photoperiod  .Watered daily, fertilized at 14 and 28 DAP
method.Chemical Preparation: Formulated trifloxysulfuron (Envoke 75WDG) and malathion (4.4EC) products. Radiolabeled [pyridinyl-2-14C]trifloxysulfuron, 1724 kBq/mg, 97% purity
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: POST at 36 DAP to 4-5 leaf stage. Trifloxysulfuron 7.5 g/ha or tank-mixed with malathion 1.3 kg/ha. 187 L/ha spray volume, 0.25% v/v non-ionic surfactant 5 μL radiolabeled trifloxysulfuron solution (1.3 kBq) in 4 drops on 3rd leaf
method.Other Information: Harvests at 0.25, 4, 8, 24, 96 hours after treatment (HAT).Leaf rinses to remove unabsorbed and cuticle-absorbed 14C
